key_points: Derek Chauvin, former Minneapolis Police officer, convicted of murdering George Floyd, to be sentenced on June 16.
Judge Peter Cahill remanded Chauvin into custody following his conviction on several charges including second-degree murder.
Chauvin is in segregated housing for his safety in a prison outside Minneapolis.
Maximum sentences under Minnesota law: 40 years for second-degree murder, 25 years for third-degree murder, and 10 years or $20,000 for second-degree manslaughter.
State guidelines suggest a presumptive sentence of 12 1/2 years for second and third-degree murder for defendants like Chauvin with no prior records.
The state has requested a tougher sentence than the guidelines recommend.
Jurors deliberated for over 10 hours across two days before reaching a verdict.
Chauvin showed no reaction to the guilty verdict in court and was taken into custody immediately.
The trial, broadcast live due to COVID-19 restrictions, included testimonies from 38 witnesses against Chauvin.
The other former officers involved - Thomas Lane, J. Alexander Kueng, and Tou Thao - charged with aiding and abetting, and their trial is upcoming.
